answer_html: Since g is both surjective and injective it is a bijection and thus the set B is denumerable.
answer_latex:
Since \emph{g} is both surjective and injective it is a bijection and
thus the set \emph{B} is denumerable.
hints_html: Start with writing a bijection \(f\): A \(\rightarrow\) N then going from there.
hints_latex:
Start with writing a bijection $f$: \emph{A} $\rightarrow$ \textbf{N} then going from
there.
hints_raw: Start with writing a bijection &fnof;: ''A'' &rarr; '''N''' then going from there.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
The core idea of this solution is to say that if the set A is denumerable, then we can remove any element a from this set and obtain a proper subset which is also denumerable. We will show below how to precisely prove that this subset is denumerable.

Since the set A is denumerable, there exists a bijection from that set to the set of natural numbers. Let \(f\) be this bijection, that is

\[\begin{aligned} f : A \to \mathbb{N}\end{aligned}\]

Let a be the element of the set A which is mapped to the integer 1, that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle a = f^{-1}(1)\end{aligned}\]

Then define the set B to be the subset containing all the elements of the set A except for the element a, that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B = A\backslash\{a\}\end{aligned}\]

Note that B is a proper subset of A. To show this subset is denumerable, define a function \(g\) to the natural numbers as follow

\[\begin{aligned} g : B &\to \mathbb{N} \\ b &\mapsto f(b)-1\end{aligned}\]

Notice that each element of the set B is mapped by \(f\) to an integer greater or equal to 2 (since we removed a who precisely was the integer mapped to 1), so the function g simply assigns the natural number just below. We claim that this \(g\) is bijective.

To show surjectivity, notice that each natural number m is the image by the function g of the element which was mapped to m+1 by the function \(f\). We can write this as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle m = g(f^{-1}(m+1))\end{aligned}\]

For injectivity, suppose that you have elements b and”b”’of the set Bsuch that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(b) = g(b')\end{aligned}\]

By definition of the function g this means that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(b)-1 = f(b')-1\end{aligned}\]

and so that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(b) = f(b')\end{aligned}\]

And since we know that the function \(f\) is a bijection (and in particular is injective) we can conclude that b = b’, and thus the function g is injective.

Since g is both surjective and injective it is a bijection and thus the set B is denumerable.

Another way to find a denumerable proper subset goes as follow:

  • use the fact that the set A has a bijection with the natural numbers to define a proper subset of all the elements mapped to an even natural number,

  • realize that this will be a proper and denumerable subset of the set A.

Details of this proof are described here.

Since the set A is denumerable there must exist a bijection g: A \(\rightarrow\) N from that set to the natural numbers. We define the set B to be all the elements of the set A that are mapped to an even number, that is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B = \{ a \in A \mid g(a) \text{ is even} \}\end{aligned}\]

We need to show that the set B is a proper subset of A and is denumerable. It is a proper subset since it doesn’t contain any element that are mapped to an odd number. To show it is denumerable, we define the function

\[\begin{aligned} h: B &\to \mathbb{N}\\ b &\mapsto \frac{g(b)}{2}\end{aligned}\]

and show that it is a bijection.

It is surjective since for any natural number m there is an element of the set A which maps to the number 2m and since that’s an even integer, that element of the set A is a member of the subset B, let’s call it b for now. Then since g(b) = 2m, then h(b) = m and thus the function h is surjective.

To show injectivity, consider two elements b and”b”’of the set B such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle h(b) = h(b')\end{aligned}\]

by definition of the function h we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{g(b)}{2} = \frac{g(b')}{2}\end{aligned}\]

and thus

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(b) = g(b')\end{aligned}\]

but since g is a bijection, it is also an injection and we can conclude that b = b’, and so the function h is injective.
sols_latex:
The core idea of this solution is to say that if the set \emph{A} is
denumerable, then we can remove any element \emph{a} from this set and
obtain a proper subset which is also denumerable. We will show below how
to precisely prove that this subset is denumerable.

Since the set \emph{A} is denumerable, there exists a bijection from
that set to the set of natural numbers. Let $f$ be this bijection, that is

\begin{align*}
f : A \to \mathbb{N}
\end{align*}

Let \emph{a} be the element of the set \emph{A} which is mapped to the
integer 1, that is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
a = f^{-1}(1)
\end{align*} Then define the set \emph{B} to be the subset containing
all the elements of the set \emph{A} except for the element \emph{a},
that is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
B = A\backslash\{a\}
\end{align*} Note that \emph{B} is a proper subset of
\emph{A}. To show this subset is denumerable, define a function $g$ to
the natural numbers as follow

\begin{align*}
g : B &\to \mathbb{N} \\
b &\mapsto f(b)-1
\end{align*}

Notice that each element of the set \emph{B} is mapped by $f$ to an
integer greater or equal to 2 (since we removed \emph{a} who precisely
was the integer mapped to 1), so the function \emph{g} simply assigns
the natural number just below. We claim that this $g$ is bijective.

To show surjectivity, notice that each natural number \emph{m} is the
image by the function \emph{g} of the element which was mapped to
\emph{m}+1 by the function $f$. We can write this as

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
m = g(f^{-1}(m+1))
\end{align*}

For injectivity, suppose that you have elements \emph{b} and''b'''of
the set \emph{B}such that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
g(b) = g(b')
\end{align*} By definition of the function \emph{g} this means that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(b)-1 = f(b')-1
\end{align*} and so that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(b) = f(b')
\end{align*} And since we know that the function $f$ is a bijection (and
in particular is injective) we can conclude that \emph{b = b',} and thus
the function \emph{g} is injective.

Since \emph{g} is both surjective and injective it is a bijection and
thus the set \emph{B} is denumerable.

Another way to find a denumerable proper subset goes as follow:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  use the fact that the set \emph{A} has a bijection with the natural
  numbers to define a proper subset of all the elements mapped to an
  even natural number,
\item
  realize that this will be a proper and denumerable subset of the set
  \emph{A}.
\end{itemize}

Details of this proof are described here.

Since the set \emph{A} is denumerable there must exist a bijection
\emph{g}: \emph{A} $\rightarrow$ \textbf{N} from that set to the natural numbers. We
define the set \emph{B} to be all the elements of the set \emph{A} that
are mapped to an even number, that is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
B = \{ a \in A \mid g(a) \text{ is even} \}
\end{align*}

We need to show that the set \emph{B} is a proper subset of \emph{A} and
is denumerable. It is a proper subset since it doesn't contain any
element that are mapped to an odd number. To show it is denumerable, we
define the function

\begin{align*}
h: B &\to \mathbb{N}\\
b &\mapsto \frac{g(b)}{2}
\end{align*} and show that it is a bijection.

It is surjective since for any natural number \emph{m} there is an
element of the set \emph{A} which maps to the number 2\emph{m} and since
that's an even integer, that element of the set \emph{A} is a member of
the subset \emph{B}, let's call it \emph{b} for now. Then since
\emph{g}(\emph{b}) = 2\emph{m}, then \emph{h}(\emph{b}) = \emph{m} and
thus the function \emph{h} is surjective.

To show injectivity, consider two elements \emph{b} and''b'''of the
set \emph{B} such that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
h(b) = h(b')
\end{align*} by definition of the function \emph{h} we have that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\frac{g(b)}{2} = \frac{g(b')}{2}
\end{align*} and thus

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
g(b) = g(b')
\end{align*} but since \emph{g} is a bijection, it is also an
injection and we can conclude that \emph{b} = \emph{b',} and so the
function \emph{h} is injective.
sols_raw:
The core idea of this solution is to say that if the set ''A'' is denumerable, then we can remove any element ''a'' from this set and obtain a proper subset which is also denumerable. We will show below how to precisely prove that this subset is denumerable.

Since the set ''A'' is denumerable, there exists a bijection from that set to the set of natural numbers. Let &fnof; be this bijection, that is

:<math> f : A \to \mathbb{N} </math>

Let ''a'' be the element of the set ''A'' which is mapped to the integer 1, that is
:<math>\displaystyle
a = f^{-1}(1)
</math>
Then define the set ''B'' to be the subset containing all the elements of the set ''A'' except for the element ''a'', that is
:<math>\displaystyle
B = A\backslash\{a\}
</math>
Note that ''B'' is a proper subset of ''A''. To show this subset is denumerable, define a function <math>g</math> to the natural numbers as follow

:<math> 
\begin{align}
g : B &\to \mathbb{N} \\
b &\mapsto f(b)-1
\end{align}
</math> 

Notice that each element of the set ''B'' is mapped by &fnof; to an integer greater or equal to 2 (since we removed ''a'' who precisely was the integer mapped to 1), so the function ''g'' simply assigns the natural number just below. We claim that this <math> g </math> is bijective.

To show surjectivity, notice that each natural number ''m'' is the image by the function ''g'' of the element which was mapped to ''m''+1 by the function &fnof;. We can write this as
:<math>\displaystyle
m = g(f^{-1}(m+1))
</math>

For injectivity, suppose that you have elements ''b'' and ''b' ''of the set ''B''such that
:<math>\displaystyle
g(b) = g(b')
</math>
By definition of the function ''g'' this means that
:<math>\displaystyle
f(b)-1 = f(b')-1
</math>
and so that
:<math>\displaystyle
f(b) = f(b')
</math>
And since we know that the function &fnof; is a bijection (and in particular is injective) we can conclude that ''b = b','' and thus the function ''g'' is injective.

Since ''g'' is both surjective and injective it is a bijection and thus the set ''B'' is denumerable.
Another way to find a denumerable proper subset goes as follow:
* use the fact that the set ''A'' has a bijection with the natural numbers to define a proper subset of all the elements mapped to an even natural number,
* realize that this will be a proper and denumerable subset of the set ''A''.

Details of this proof are described here.

Since the set ''A'' is denumerable there must exist a bijection ''g'': ''A'' &rarr; '''N''' from that set to the natural numbers. We define the set ''B'' to be all the elements of the set ''A'' that are mapped to an even number, that is
:<math>\displaystyle
B = \{ a \in A \mid g(a) \text{ is even} \}
</math>

We need to show that the set ''B'' is a proper subset of ''A'' and is denumerable. It is a proper subset since it doesn't contain any element that are mapped to an odd number. To show it is denumerable, we define the function
:<math>\begin{align}
h: B &\to \mathbb{N}\\
b &\mapsto \frac{g(b)}{2}
\end{align}</math>
and show that it is a bijection.

It is surjective since for any natural number ''m'' there is an element of the set ''A'' which maps to the number 2''m'' and since that's an even integer, that element of the set ''A'' is a member of the subset ''B'', let's call it ''b'' for now. Then since ''g''(''b'') = 2''m'', then ''h''(''b'') = ''m'' and thus the function ''h'' is surjective. 

To show injectivity, consider two elements ''b'' and ''b' ''of the set ''B'' such that
:<math>\displaystyle
h(b) = h(b')
</math>
by definition of the function ''h'' we have that
:<math>\displaystyle
\frac{g(b)}{2} = \frac{g(b')}{2}
</math>
and thus
:<math>\displaystyle
g(b) = g(b')
</math>
but since ''g'' is a bijection, it is also an injection and we can conclude that ''b'' = ''b','' and so the function ''h'' is injective.
statement_html: Let A be a denumerable set. Prove that there exists a proper subset B of A such that B is denumerable.
statement_latex:
Let \emph{A} be a denumerable set. Prove that there exists a proper
subset \emph{B} of \emph{A} such that \emph{B} is denumerable.
statement_raw: Let ''A'' be a denumerable set. Prove that there exists a proper subset ''B'' of ''A'' such that ''B'' is denumerable.
